plant.description: Mountain mahogany; a genus of shrubs and small trees in the rose family, native to the western United States and northern Mexico.

basics.description: Mountain mahogany; a genus of shrubs and small trees in the rose family, native to the western United States and northern Mexico.

toxins.name: Cyanogenic glycosides, which metabolize and break down to release cyanide (specifically hydrogen cyanide)
toxins.concentration_notes: The toxic cyanogenic glycosides are generally concentrated within the leaves of the plant and the seeds of its fruit2. Severe toxicity is relatively uncommon unless a large amount of the plant is ingested2. Furthermore, the seeds must be physically compromised to pose a danger; if a cat swallows a seed completely whole without chewing it, the cyanide is not released and toxicity is not expected

symptoms.name: Respiratory distress (panting, gasping for breath, or labored breathing)
symptoms.notes:
This is typically one of the most prominent signs of cyanide poisoning, occurring because the toxin severely hampers the body's ability to utilize oxygen at the cellular level45.
2. Unusual Gum Color (Bright Red Gums)

symptoms.name: Unusually red or pink gums (bright red mucous membranes)
symptoms.notes:
This distinct symptom happens because the cells are unable to extract oxygen from the blood. The blood remains fully oxygenated, causing the gums and mucous membranes to appear bright red while the body's tissues are essentially suffocating35.
3. Dilated Pupils

symptoms.name: Dilated pupils
symptoms.notes:
Abnormally large pupils act as an indicator of severe systemic stress and neurological impairment from the rapid lack of usable oxygen3....
4. Excessive Drooling

symptoms.name: Excessive drooling (hypersalivation)
symptoms.notes:
Salivating much more than usual can be one of the earlier, acute signs of toxic exposure before severe neurological decline sets in5.
5. Shock, Seizures, and Coma

symptoms.name: Shock, seizures (convulsions), loss of consciousness, and coma
symptoms.notes: These extreme neurological and cardiovascular symptoms manifest as the oxygen deprivation peaks. Cyanide poisoning acts very quickly; if prompt veterinary attention (which may include oxygen therapy and specific antidotes) is not provided, it rapidly progresses to death

treatments.name: Supportive Care
treatments.description: Provide supportive care for gastrointestinal upset and monitor. Consult a veterinarian.
